title: 111_hr2418
content: "Mynisha's Law" is the short title of this Act. The findings section follows. Congress finds that with an estimated 24,500 gangs operating in the United States, gang violence and drug trafficking are serious problems causing harm to innocent victims, including children. A tragic gang-related shooting in San Bernardino, California resulted in the death of an 11-year-old girl and serious injury to her 14-year-old sister, highlighting the ongoing struggle many communities face in combating gang violence and protecting children from senseless violence. The Federal Government aims to combat gang violence by targeting criminal street gangs responsible for distributing illegal drugs in the United States. Increased commitment to law enforcement and resources are needed to implement prevention and intervention programs focusing on at-risk youth. Designation as a comprehensive gang prevention and relief area. A unit of local government, city, county, tribal government, or group of counties can apply to the Attorney General for designation as a Comprehensive Gang Prevention and Relief Area. The Attorney General establishes criteria for evaluating applications based on gang crime levels and violent crime in the area. The Attorney General evaluates applications for designation as a Comprehensive Gang Prevention and Relief Area based on criteria including the relationship between violent crime and gang activity, existing collaboration on gang prevention, and other relevant factors determined by the Attorney General. The Interagency Gang Prevention Task Force is established. The Attorney General establishes an Interagency Gang Prevention Task Force to coordinate Federal assistance for Comprehensive Gang Prevention and Relief Areas. The Task Force includes representatives from various government departments and focuses on creating a comprehensive gang prevention response, including early childhood intervention, at-risk youth intervention, literacy, employment, community policing, and comprehensive measures. The Interagency Gang Prevention Task Force prioritizes funding for Comprehensive Gang Prevention and Relief Areas through various programs such as Child Care and Development Block Grant Act, Even Start programs, Healthy Start Initiative, Head Start Act, and 21st Century Community Learning Centers program. The curr_chunk lists various programs including the Job Corps program, community development block grant program, Gang Resistance Education and Training projects, Juvenile Accountability Block Grant program, and Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant. The Task Force shall report annually to Congress and the Attorney General on funding needs and outcomes for designated Comprehensive Gang Prevention and Relief Areas, including an evidence-based analysis of best practices and outcomes. The Task Force will report annually to Congress and the Attorney General on funding needs and outcomes for designated Comprehensive Gang Prevention and Relief Areas, including an analysis of Federal funding adequacy and any programmatic shortfalls identified, with a request for new funding or reprogramming of existing funds if needed. Authorization of appropriations is granted to meet the needs identified by the Task Force for the purposes of this Act.
